posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9474613
Any licensed game that becomes an original ip. So stuff like Shatterhand and DeCap Attack, Blazing Lazers and Mario USA. It lets the gameplay be the main focus rather then the ip attached to it and gives the developer free reign to rerelease it or expand on it with a sequel without dealing with the copyright it had slapped on it. Its the one case of localization i wish had happened more.

Wario Blast. In Japan, it was just a regular Bomberman Game Boy game. But the localized version added Wario as a playable character.
Also thought the plot, even if there was barely one, was a bit more interesting. In the original Bomberman GB, Bomberman simply gets his things stolen by the Madbombers. In the Wario Blast story line, Wario somehow finds a portal that links his world to Bomberman's world. Wario goes there to gather resources and minions and Bomberman must stop him, giving you the hero route or villain route depending on who you choose.

>>9483058
I think it's mostly the perception of what makes a "good" translation for many people. Phoenix Wright is loved and it practically was a Working Designs style when it started out because of its attempts to go "no this isn't Japan what are you talking about haha hey Maya sure loves to eat HAMBURGERS am I right". But overall anime and Japanese media has become big and ingrained enough that the Working Designs/4Kids/Saban levels of translating something is more met with derision than "oh boy anime". Even when Nintendo tossed memes into localized scripts of their games, people are more likely to groan and wish they weren't there now.

I think part of it too is that Working Designs translated Magic Knights Rayearth, which has the honor of being the last western Sega Saturn game. If it were anything else, sure, but Rayearth was an established franchise and WD putting on their trademark brand of humor soured a lot to them: even back when the game was new, people felt it was an awkward and out of place translation for the game because the anime was available and already had fans. So you have a game that hits a lot of "oh should I check this out" flags (last console release in the west, based on a beloved series, etc) and get hit with "eh, they made it worse" is sort of an "the Emperor isn't wearing any clothes" moment for them.

Also they put an ammo system into Silhouette Mirage and that personally rankled me because it meant you never wanted to experiment with different weapons due to the cost to use them, then they added grinding for money on top of it. They frequently mistook tedium for difficulty.

>>9477134
Japan has an inclination to do stories of the young because of initial post-WWII ideals. They were slower in growth and did not lend to people of that generation immediately creating new stories. It took Japan longer, like the first Godzilla struggled to get made because of anti-Japanese sentiment. It impacted them culturally and they didn't have a boom. By the time thedid rapidly expand, it was younger people making the stories, who had a different perception of WWII and Japan as a whole. since the 60's and 70's Japan has just very heavily leaned into using young people in media.

On the contrast to what the west was doing. The growth of hollywood never stopped during the war, only shifted. And the stream of stories was always on the middle aged. It wasn't till the 50's that the west also started incorporating young people into their stories.

I think FFX suffers from some slight issues, as far as intent and facts though. Auron is supposed to old at age 35 and even refers to himself as young 10 years ago, when he was 25. Yet we have a maester who has served for some 70 years. I think what happens is characters get designed and created and then put into a story and not organically written. So it's part of the overall media franchise machine.

Yea, very much so. In a normal play through his toolbox kit is interesting. I think Mighty Guard becomes the only really viable overdrive.

Kimahri is a litmus test for people. He can do anything except summon. On a play through he can fill any role you might want more of. FF10 is so piss ass easy I doubt anyone made him a healer. However, he is actually incredibly useful if you give him the nul-spells, especially in the parts of the game where you don't have yuna.

Putting him down Tidus's path gives another haste user and keeps his melee stats up. You can rikku him for the steal/use and still decent speed stats. Lulu's path is a unique one, as for most of the game lulu is your only nuker and you can get magic boost weapons for kimahri and he can help clean up enemies weak to that.

Wakka and Auron paths are fine, but don't offer that much, unless you just wanted to use Kimahri over those characters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9477718
My first year in college I had some classes with people who were borderline illiterate and couldn't do remedial math but were still delusional enough to think that they could hack through and become nurses or programmers or whatever. So instead of just admitting they were in over their heads they plowed ahead, submitted their papers, took the tests, waited for their obligatory "you tried, here's a C-" and then they flunked out after one semester.

That's what the game.com reminds me of. It's easy to think that this was just a cynical attempt to separate suckers from their money but I think there was actually a kind of tragic sincerity behind it. Like, Tiger really thought they'd stepped it up. It was an actual console! With Sonic! And Resident Evil! They were rubbing shoulders with Sony and Sega like a real game company...just long enough to embarrass themselves and confirm they didn't belong before withdrawing in shame.

Like, Imagine being the guys who put together that RE2 port. It died on arrival and was always going to but...it's not nothing. The game actually has a lot of content to it. Redundant, shitty content but somebody still had to make it and they probably had to put some effort into it. I honestly want to know what became of the people who made these things. Did they know they were working on a thankless task? Did they think they were making the game.com's greatest hit? Were they cynical mercenaries or dreamers whose dreams were shattered? Why does my autistic brain think about these things?

>>9484630
>imagine playing duke3d where you can only strafe and not turn.

I look at the Game.Com hardware and I just don't know what to say about it. On one side, Tiger was on the right path with many of the ideas. The handheld has enough buttons, it was the first with a touch screen and stylus pen before the DS. The system is 8-bit like the Gameboy, and is in some ways better and worse. It has a faster CPU, and can throw some pretty big (for the system) sprites on screen. It seems to be able to play back audio samples. The weird midi-music system it has seems to be horrible. Games run at 5-10FPS. Most of the games for this system look partially broken or completely broken. It is still an evolution over the tiger electronic games. Look at this game based on the movie The Lost World:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R9sQwkI2yVo&t=249s

This is one of those games that would look good in screen shots, because some of the sprites and art do look good. But, it also looks bad at the same time. I feel like there was almost something there with the Game.com. But by 1998, the Game Boy Color was out on the market at the same price.

You basically get as much as you'll most likely ever get out of a Street Fighter character by literally looking at them fight, and often that isn't even necessary. You still get the SNK approach in SF characters though, like Karin in A3 or Remy in TS.

I'm really torn about it. This new black Trinitron has much better geometry than my WEGA, probably by virtue of having a rounded screen instead of the WEGA's flat glass, BUT the convergence issue you mention is all too real. Subtitles in games like Shenmue (where subtitles are difference colors, not just white/black) look really awful, but otherwise this new Trinitron is absolute king for 8-bit and 16-bit games. I forget just how good Hard Corps looks on a big tube.
I read up about how to go about fixing convergence though and it looks like there's three ways to go about it, depending on the gravity of the issue.
>Move the Horizontal alignment physical thingy inside the chassis.
>Move the Vertical alignment rings around the yoke itself.
>Stick more convergence strips inside the yoke, maybe even move magnets around.
In my case, the convergence is only really off on the borders of the image, so I only really need to play around with the "convergence strips", whatever that is. Will look into some home-made strips though, since I really doubt I'll be able to find these things on sale at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485672
>That's not how TVL works.
Stupid faggot, that's exactly how it works

TVL = Horizontal Resolution
SNES/Genesis after PAR adjustment = 292x224

Assuming no overscan you can display all detail with 292TVL and and anything more than that and it looks oversharpened.
But CRTs always have overscan so you can never get it perfect.

Example
Top
15 inch consumer CRT component

Bottom
500 line PVM 14 inch RGB

The lower TVL looks far far better
But even that isn't perfect since you have screen-door effect because of the dot pitch being bigger than the pixel pitch.
The only way to achieve perfection is near-neighbour scaling into 12000-20000 PPI displays which is still a long way off.

>>9488437
Oh hey good timing, you asked right as I was checking back on this thread
I had two wired Retrofighters Brawler64s that crapped out on me. Basically the analog stick started dropping inputs, so for example if you were running forward as Link in OoT he would stop and start - essentially unusable. Both had the exact same problem.
Unfortunately they both had fallen just outside the warranty window, and their support didn't even reply when I sent them like a "Hey, anything I can try to do to fix these?"
About a year later someone on twitter was asking about them, and I outlined that whole chain of events to them and said that I don't recommend them at all. From that tweet, their PR/customer support team reached out to me and ultimately actually shipped me two of the newer wireless versions by way of apology. And the wireless one has held up a lot better than the originals. At least, so far.
So maybe the takeaway is, they used to be utter crap, and now are (hopefully) a lot better. The analog stick on all of these these is just kind of weird though.

In the interim I used the wired Retro-Bit Tribute64 (which is modeled after the famous Hori N64 controller) and I actually liked this a lot better than any of the Brawler64s. The only problem with these is that the connector has an absolute death grip on the controller port, which is why I switched back to the wireless Brawler64 for right now - since I didn't want to be unplugging and replugging that controller all the time, and wireless controllers just keep things a bit more tidy. You know how it is.

There is an N64 controller purist on this board who will tell you that the analog stick sensitivity and deadzones of any of these 3rd party controllers is crap compared to the original - he's got charts and whatnot to back it up. He's probably right, but it's never really bothered me and or caused any real problems.

Of these I'd recommend the Tribute64 first.

My FW900 has just suddenly started refusing to turn on if it's cold. More specifically when I try to turn it on it'll make the initial degauss click, then a horrible loud fizzle noise and bright flashes will appear on the left and right parts of the screen. The protector mode will then be activated and the LED will flash amber. If I heat up the tube to a little above room temperature (it's fairly cold in the house) then it will turn on as usual, albeit it will sound a bit more crackly and staticky than usual. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Majora's Mask has an awesome concept. The world is hauntingly moody and even basic stuff like the buildings in Clock Town have a really off-kilter aesthetic that you don't find anywhere else. The personalities of the characters are really memorable, and stick out like a darkly proto-animal crossing. The time limit is a really unique idea.

But the game gets bogged down in slow-gameplay drudgery. Waiting for characters and time-of-day events. Annoying stuff like the powder keg mission - the games clunky controls being put to the test, and if you screw up it's another boring few minutes hobbling forwards as the Goron. The game is full of cool ideas that take a long time to do because the game system isn't really designed around them,

Ocarina blows it out of the water from a gameplay pacing perspective. :)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9488078
I'd rather add a little exposition for each. I'd like to see the same from other anons if you can spare the time, bare lists are boring.

>First
Adventure of Link: rented it by chance the first time a friend loaned me his NES.
>Favorite
Majora's Mask: great high concept for both story and gameplay, and the subquests actually trump the main content.
>Least Favorite
Minish Cap: too generic and the concept is wasted on a 2D game.
>Track
The Windmill/Song of Storms track in OoT, or maybe the WW overworld/sailing music: they're just neat.
>Item
Mirror Shield: it's a good idea for a 3D gameplay-item and it's cool there's both puzzle-solving and battle applications.
>Character
Happy Mask Salesman: nothing about his appearance, characterization, and role fails to be iconic.
>Enemy
AoL Iron Knuckles; they encapsulate the game's best and worst qualities.

>Extra: Favorite Dungeon
Spirit Temple: best balance of a good unique concept and general old-school dungeon trappings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9488138
MM is a not particularly rare example of something very idiosyncratic in which what people hate about it is exactly what other people love. From a mainstream flagship franchise's perspective it was a weird gamble, but it's great at some point something like it could be made at all, and it's no wonder it became a cult classic.

The degree of dedication you had to put in to stakeout places and shadow characters until you pieced everything together was what made it so immersive and satisfying. Finally completing the Kafei/Anjou Quest after many loops of investigation, trial and error is one of the most memorable experiences I remember related to any videogame, and it's not even something you need to do to "beat" the game.

The 3DS remake's revamping of the Save system, and the Bomber's notebook in which you're literally given specific times and places were huge letdowns. It's a bit sad it will become the first and only way many people will get to experience one of the best games ever made. The ironic implication is that Aonuma himself clearly didn't quite understand what about the original game resonated with the players who liked it; and thus the remake became something that people who didn't like the original would find simply tolerable at best, and the rest would be sure to hate.

The idea is you're supposed to revisit those missions on your second play through with your new parts and build. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played the PS1 game when I was like... 7 years old, and I really liked building my robot. That stuff was really compelling. The customisation is the real meat on the bones of this game, which is fortunate because the gameplay itself was pretty weak. But in fairness, I can't criticise it too harshly for that, it's only like when you play a mediocre RPG because you still get that nice dopamine hit from getting sweet loot.

To me, a real mech game should have a cockpit view and obtuse controls that make you really feel like you're a PILOT, not just that you're playing as a sentient robot. If they can pull off something that feels a bit more realistic and less weeby, I might be more interested.

But yeah, I think there are a lot of hipsters who claim the game is better than it is because it's FromSoft, much like with King's Field. I find it funny because they act like FromSoft have always had this enlightened genius game design when in reality, like most successes, Dark Souls was just kind of a lucky experimental combination of the right ingredients.

>>9483981
You just let the OPL desktop software a folder on your computer (mine's on a laptop) and set it up to be sharable. Pic related, there's only three folders you care about and the full art asset set can be downloaded pre-formatted at under 200mb

From my cheat sheet:

>04/26/2021

>This is a SHARED FOLDER FOR OPEN PS2 LOADER, CONNECTED VIA ETHERNET CABLE
>-I configured a static IP address on my network adapter for this; you'll have
>to go to network and sharing > change adapter settings > ethernet > IPV4
>to convert it back to dynamic IP from current static

>I changed share settings for home and public; might want to lock those back down.

>If you want to remove the shared file path (C:\***\PS2SMB), go to properties/sharing/advanced sharing/uncheck 'share this folder'

>>9484165
>>9484171
OPL is short for Open PS2 Loader. It's software you run on your PS2 that lets you boot games from an internal hard drive, a USB drive or via your network using SMB.
It's pretty sweet, honestly. You can buy a memory card online for maybe $15 tops that's preloaded everything you need to run it on your PS2. You just plug the memory card into either slot before the console boots and you're good to go.
Setting up OPL itself is another matter entirely, but it's really well documented.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484165
>>9484417
It's also an accompanying managerial application what you use to properly format ISOs (IE, make sure they're named with the proper formatting), manage art assets, and convert CD-format PS2 games (Bin+cue) to ghetto ISOs you can play through the utility

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484643
>Is there any difference between the IDE to SATA converters? Obviously it's all chinkshit, but is it all pretty much the same?
I noticed there's some that don't have the master/slave switch. This is a thing I became aware while homebrewing my Xbox. I don't know if that would cause any problems. Due to the low price the only option is just to try them out.

>I think I saw that you could use a 3.5 or a 2.5 drive, but I assume a 2.5 would be better for the space. I just don't know what all of this looks like once its in the guts of the machine.
I use SATA drives (2.5 ones). This is how it looks. It kind of dangles from the network adapter. As long as you're not moving the PS2 around there is no danger of it falling off. Somebody sold 3D printer "holders" to make it more sturdy, but I haven't had any problems in a year of using this setup.

>And for HDDs, is there an upper limit on specs that the PS2 even benefits from?
I think the limit is 2 TB but that's really overkill. The main issue is that any HDD you obtain has to be detectable by the PS2 for formatting. It may well be that the expensive HDD you buy simply won't be detected and there is nothing you can do. My suggestion is to salvage some SATA HDDs from old laptops or second-hand stores. I got two 500 GB and one 320 GB drives this way and only cost me $30 from a guy on facebook marketplace. All of them worked, luckily.

The PS2 won't benefit from higher speeds since most games have tied logic to the PS2 reading speed, so its capped.

The current program used for feeding games to the drive is called HDL-Batch. It has been updated this year and I literally used it yesterday. Now it has an user interface and can tell you if the ISO is corrupt or if its already in the drive etc. You format the drive in the PS2, get it out and connect it to the PC with an USB to SATA cable (very cheap), the program dectects the drive and you just select the games you want to install.

>>9484864
>Would a 3.5" drive still dangle, or sit more flush?
The 3.5 IDE drive will just fill the space so there would be no dangling. The space was made for those in mind.
I opted for the 2.5 SATA drives due to the issues of:
- needing the SATA to IDE adapter OR the original PS2 network adapter.
- needing to get an IDE to USB for the PC (the IDE needs it's own power so it will turn on in the Xbox/PS2 but not when you connect it to the PC with the SATA to IDE adapter).
- the internet scared me with stories of IDE drives dying out of the blue.
- the current abundance of SATA drives being thrown for pennies by people who don't know better and me being unable to find an IDE drive that wasn't being sold full-price/new.

>Oh, you don't just do all that through Explorer file management? I guess I didn't notice that when reading this stuff.
Windows will just not even acknowledge you added connected a drive if it's formatted for PS2. Yes. It's confusing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485430
Obviously the hard drive goes in the PS2.
OPL has an option to format it for PS2 use, regardless what was in it before.
It just needs to recognize it (there's a website for compatibilities but its incomplete and given the unlikeness of finding the exact drive it's better to get it for cheap).

Once formatted you can add games to it. The fastest is to take the drive out and connect via USB to the PC.
Windows won't recognize the drive, but if you use HDL batch it will appear there. There you just select the ISOs and BIN/CUEs you want to add and it loads them up.
There are other ways to add stuff like network or USB but that's slow as fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9485789
It couldn't hurt to grab a game or two that you're interested in since there's still some good stuff that can be had for cheap out there, but if I were you I would throw CFW on your new PS2 and get some way to play ISOs going. You'd definitely get the most games for your money that way, and 99% of stuff works exactly the same as it would from a real CD or DVD with a little bit of setup.
If you read this thread there have been several posts with good resources about where to get started. Basically, you'll need a memory card with Free MCBoot preinstalled (you can get these on eBay or Amazon) and you'll need to install OPL Manager on your PC to manage your games. If you have a fat PS2, you should spend a little more money and get a hard drive set up for it. If you have a slim you should stick to playing games over ethernet. You can play games over USB on ether model, but it's not as good as the other methods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just finished it after having skipped it back in the day for whatever reason.

Solid sequel. Feels a bit by like I'm just going through the motions from Prime 1 but its a damn solid game considering Retro shat it out in barely what, a year and a half? Dark World gives it its own identity, and the level design overall is some of the best in the series with criss-crossing paths and multi-layered levels galore. Specifically the underwater section in Torvus is great with its central room and the corridors running around it which you figure out by constantly jumping back and forth in the world.

Difficulty is massively overrated, its not significantly harder than MP1. I was dreading the boost guardian after hearing so much about him yet beat him on my second try.

I'm not too big a fan of the Ing as the main enemy, they come off as Zergling ripoffs but with DARKNESS and feel very impersonal. In fact, the whole Luminoth conflict just makes me feel like an errand boy with how video gamey it is. (Oh glorious Samus, go to the three temples and get the macguffin for we are fucking useless)

Then the Space pirates and Dark Samus are just kind of there for some reason.

If you like Prime 1, its essentially more Prime for you to sink your teeth into. Defo worth a go if you haven't played it.

In the dark Ing Hive level where the spinning reactor room normally is in Sanctuary Fortress I didn't notice the glass that divides you from the reactor which normally was there in the light version was gone in the dark version and spent hours looking for a way into the dark reactor room.

>>9489212
Boost guardian is hated because if you don't do the thing, then it's logically impossible to beat him on hard mode. He'll just do more damage than you.

The thing is to, you know, hit him when he's just a puddle on the floor. You can hit enemies when they're goop on the walls or floor, but a lot of players don't do this because it requires manual aiming in a GCN Metroid game. Many players assume you're only allowed to hit him when he's not a puddle, because that's the only time the game will lock onto him.

I played on a real SEGA Saturn one time in my life, decades ago at my cousin's house one summer. He had the NiGHTS Sampler and I think Street FIghter Alpha 1 or 2. It's a fantastic game and makes me feel like I'm rediscovering a lost part of my childhood, since the most I ever played was up to Gillwing. There's also Game Boy in general, since I never owned a Game Boy growing up, but knew kids that had one. Harvest Moon I constantly heard about from Nintendo Power but never tried until I got a proper emulator handheld with GB form factor.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9482451
A short game with good atmosphere and great soundtrack.

Reading through the replies though. It is not like the later games or anything like the genre it created. It's a turn based real time game. It's more fun in single player. Playing Warrior without magic or a bow for ranged attacking is braindead. It's old in it's way it expects players to adapt. You can find traces of Jagged Alliance on how to deal with various combinations of enemy AIs. Very simple, but sped up due to real time clickety click and fun.

It wasn't designed with 100h playtime in mind. Mods for faster walking, Adria near town center and higher difficulties in single player are good. Expansion Hellfire is garbage.

Have fun. If you don't just leave it. It was big back then, but games were different in the 90ties.

>>9482451
A couple tips:

Hold shift to attack while standing in place. This is super useful for corralling monsters on one side of a doorway while you stand on the other side whacking them one on one.

If you see a dying villager outside of the church that means you got a quest called The Butcher. Somewhere on level 2 you will see a small room, when you open it he will come out and wreck your shit. The easiest way to kill him is to lead him to a spot where one or two grates are next to a door. Go through the door, slam it in his face, and then pepper him with bow shots while he walks back and forth like a retard. It'll take a while, but it's foolproof.

If you're looking at majority of 6th generation consoles games that doesn't include Xbox, that may be true. But perfectly? You're too optimistic about that. We're just now getting chips with 2017 flagship mobile phone architectures. No android phone so far can run Rogue Squadron 2 on Dolphin at full speed on mobile outside of hacked iPhone 12s mostly due to CPU brute forcing. The Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 can probably do it but it is unreleased until 2023. You're looking until 2028 if the time lag is the same to get this power in a $150 device. For most of 6th generation, you're already pretty much there with the T618 and this is a chip that was already released in 2019 by Unisoc which is now just trickling down to this pricepoint. 6th generation is where mobile chips are going to feel like time stopped until someone is willing to eat a loss with a flagship mobile SOC on a device selling cheaply before the 2028 timeline when the chips become cheap enough.

Make sure you check the 'Sold' amount next to the listing. A reputable seller will typically have 50+ items sold for a decent one.

Also check and gauge the price range of typical items being sold do you make sure you're not getting ripped off. Aka for ex: do not pay $90 for a Miyoo Mini when it's supposed to be $40 to $60 etc on AliExpress if you track the item each week throughout the week.

I mention the whole price range thing because they can either overcharge you or have "a really good deal" which equivalates to a scam since the item will never ship or you'll get a PM stating "Dear friend (we don't have that item) etc"

I haven't had that happen to me yet but I've read some have had it happen here.

If you're ever unsure just copy and paste the link into this thread and ask for someone to vet it out to get a second opinion etc.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9485101
Put JELOS onto the first SD card. Then when you feel like playing N64, take out the first SD card so it boots into Android and learn how to tweak MupenFZPro to run N64 games decently.

Make sure that when you're in Android mode to use the touch screen, swipe down, and apply the "CPU Boost" icon that's shaped like a processor since you're going to need the boost for emulation and it's not enabled by default so without it, it makes N64 appear sluggish.

Put some PC ports on it via Port Master. Compile Super Mario 64 PC port for the RG353V. Idk get creative, squeeze that machine to do everything and hoard ROM sets.

That all depends however if you got the Android capable one. If not, the Linux only one is gimped in comparison. And make sure you get a big SD card from a good brand like SanDisk or Samsung cause the default Chinese SD cards they give you are shit tier in the long run for reliability.

>>9485792
I wouldn't emulate on iOS devices. It's possible but man you gotta really know your tech shit to pull it off. Plus the major exploits to jailbreak those devices are done by literally one dude.

Almost got it working once on an iPad but if retro emulation is your thing, stick to Android phones if you're going the phone route.

A lot of dudes say the Xiaomi chink android smartphones are good if you can get them used around $100 to $200. However a good Razer Kishi V2 controller is like $50 to $80, but it's USB C so there's no input lag etc and it looks pretty fucking solid.

You can also check out the Odin handhelds or the Aya Neo devices. They might have the performance you're looking for regarding Sega Saturn and Dreamcast but honestly I don't know since I haven't looked into it personally.

All I'm saying is be prepared to shell out near $200 to $300+ for a device or phone + controller setup for the workflow you want.

posts.name: Anonymous

Random idea but do you have a Nintendo Switch from the original 2 years of launch? An idea I thought of is to just mod one via the softmod hack and just put Android on it with emulators frontends.

Not sure how to handle the OLED request cause I don't give that much of a shit about the panels. Even on the same idea, you can probably hack a Nintendo Switch OLED edition but I think those require hardware mod chips.

For your use case despite the gay screen requirement thing, I'd say look into the Anbernic RG353P.

It's a comfy device and fucking awesome for SNES and GBA which is what I personally use it for. Imagine a very modern take on a Super Nintendo controller with stacked shoulder buttons and very good dpad and buttons.

If you're going the Anbernic route for any of their devices, always get the one thats Android AND Linux compatible, not just Linux compatible.

Reason being is that the ability to boot into Android is really nice if you want better N64 or PSP performance later etc.

posts.com:
Silent hill 1: never played it

Silent hill 2: Goated, however, the horror was okay at best. I found myself laughing at the monsters most of the time. The puzzles were absolutely god-tier. There was a particular puzzle that managed to turn a group of 7 people into a frenzy on deciding what was the best answer for it. Highly recommend this game and the best in the series for me. The puzzle I am talking about is the coin puzzle. Also shout out Stanley Coleman, reading his logs in the hospital was epic.

Silent hill 3: Honestly one of the weirdest games I have played, I found myself questioning the game more than anything. The horror aspect was just not there for me honestly. Puzzles are dank as always.

Silent hill homecoming: hilarious yet fun game, I believe this game mixed with silent hill 2 would have been a masterpiece. Would be hard to pull off though.

silent hill downpour: did not finish it, forgettable game.

I do see that people are putting silent hill 2 & 3 over RE 4 and I just do not agree. Besides puzzles, it just does not compare. You could even argue atmosphere but it's not a strong case enough for me.

You could say I have a bias since I broke my horror game hymen with RE4 then played dead space after that. I would even put dead Space 1&2 over the silent hill games. That is just me.

This is not discounting silent hill games since I would play silent hill 2 in a heartbeat. Other than that, it's not the goat for me.

My first couple horror games were: RE4, dead space 1&2, Condemed 2: Bloodshot

posts.com: it seems a faux pas to say, but i think RE4 really is the best horror game. it has a lot of action and 80s tier one-liners, but it's easy to forget about some of the legitimately creepy moments. as a kid, i always ran through the village at night when you first get ashley because of how scary it was; being in this pitch black, rainy farmland with a bunch of demented spaniards lurking in the dark is pretty unsettling. that's to say nothing of the first time you see regenerators, or even stranger shit like the bag in the dumpster that convulses. the way the game uses music to build atmosphere is fantastic too -- e.g., the merchant theme which is calm and protective but always serves as a warning of something sinister to come. the game's ability to create a sense of claustrophobia and dread is frankly amazing.

posts.com: I've been getting into this genre the past few months and one aspect of this genre that really surprised me was the realization of just how small it really was. There's a million RE games, a handful of SH games that actually matter, and then a lot of one off shit that either never caught on or was based on an some IP at the time. RE has definitely cemented itself as a pop culture icon, so why did the actual survival horror genre die so quickly exactly? By seventh gen it was all but dead, with only a mild resurgence in recent years. Perhaps it's part of an appeal to the genre but so many other games in this genre generally feel more along the lines of "passion projects" with a number of apparent flaws that would turn off average consumers, only RE and SH really feel like true "big budget" experiences. I was only born in 98 but to anyone that grew up with it just how long did RE stay relevant? It feels like RE2 was definitely still fresh in the minds of people but by RE3 it seems like there was a decline in interest overall.

>>9487436
This is a great question, and I'll try to answer it from my own point of view. Personally, I feel that the only games that have ever tried to imitate Resident Evil are its own series, and Dino Crisis 1. This is even debatable, as truthfully the only REAL survival horror games, as in games that both combine survival AND horror, without going down the more action heavy route, are RE1, REmake, and Dino Crisis.

Back to the subject though, you'll notice all of REs knock-offs barely ever tried to imitate its style. Even Silent Hill, its greatest rip-off, is absolutely nothing like Resident Evil. It has virtually no item management, and ammo is not scarce at all. Most of the games just try to rip off its camera angle and let you shoot monsters. But how many tried to copy the Mansion, or added in interesting, well-thought backtracking? How many are actually scarce on ammunition, or force you to really strategize how you go through each room? It just doesn't exist. I'm not sure if Resident Evil was just that good, or the developers were just flat out lazy and all of the clones were cash grabs. But they aren't very good in comparison, and they all lack polish.

the *actual*, real thing that separates a "survival horror" game from something else is the true permanence of consequence, aka putting the onus of survival onto the player regardless of how easy or hard it is to achieve in actuality

RE1 is a survival horror game because it has truly finite resources and if you choose to shoot them onto a wall the game wont take pity on you and divine more resources from some enemys asshole, unlike RE4, dead space or the evil within

Call of Cthulhu DCOTE has light elements of survival horror but it doesnt commit into the design in its linear gauntlet that doesnt leave much space for consistent systems or long term consequences to ever really unlock the meaning of the label

RE4 is an action game and any type of mild (perceived) resource scarcity in that game only exists to incentivize actually interacting with the full action mechanics of the game (conserving resources by hitting weakspots and using the melee to either hit entire crowds or immediately damage one enemy as much as possible, using the knife, using the environmental tools) instead of just unloading into the crowd which would completely break the encounter design

>>9488479
I think SH3's strengths get overshadowed i general. It's a weird game in the series, it acts as a continuation of SH1's plot while telling a more personal narrative about Heather like SH2, making it feel "redundant" in ways. SH3 both tries to tell a deeper narrative happening around the protagonist and those around her but also have her experience her own personal journey, it's a very ambitious narrative that, overall, I would say works out well but doesn't feel quite as cohesive as the prior two entries. Generally I think people see SH3 as having "less meaning" in what the game, and this is true in a few regards but still pretty inaccurate to the overall. Honestly I think the symbolism and themes go over people's heads because they're so heavily based in the feminine experience. If you're a guy I feel like it's likely you just kind of don't think about things like the game's various menstrual imagery, though some things like the hole leading to the final boss are hard to miss.

I always have a hard time deciding between SH1 and SH3 as my personal favorite. SH3 has a lot going for it with the most refined gameplay and graphics of the series, but it's also the most obviously compromised of the first three games. The game has essentially no exploration outside of the dungeons and a handful of "grab thing, walk a room over, use thing" moments. It's a great game on its own merits, but how it compares to prior entries and their strengths gives a lot of differing thoughts. I would say that, as simply a "video game", that SH3 is the best, as to be expected being the newest, but it's clear pure gameplay is not why people love horror games.

>you literally just called it a "straight up action game"
That's the gameplay genre. "Horror" isn't a video game genre, it's a theme. As a video game, it's an action game, and it has a horror theme.
>anyone who has actually played re4 knows you spend like half the time rearranging shit in your inventory
I'll give you the opportunity to redeem this line of argument then. What does physically rearranging the position of your guns and ammo rather than just having hard caps on what you can carry do in RE4 to make it a fundamental part of the game? I don't think it really amounts to anything, it's just an interesting way to cap your equipment progressively, the same way another game would just tell you "you can only carry 2 guns" and the ammo counter maxes at 48.
The reason people talk about inventory management with the older RE games is because you have to have slots open in your inventory in order to pick up the key items you need to progress. In order to have slots open, you have to sacrifice the ability to carry something else. RE4's attache case only prevents you from playing with every gun at the same time and gathering thousands of bullets, not to be an obstacle to progress.

>It's pretty janky. 30 is alright though.

The problem with overclocking the original Star Fox is how the game is tied to the framerate. the game music is timed to the games crap framjerate. For example, Star Fox on real hardware:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zaWPTnHUEAY
(note how the intro cut sscene ends at the right music cue)

30fps overclock:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZ6pWTe-Sd8

Polygon cutscene ends way before the music ends. The devs designed Star Fox around its awful framerate. In order to make Star Fox look right at 60fps, the game would have to be modified to match the timing of the new framerate. I always heard that EAD synced the first stage Corneria to Dire Straights Money for Nothing (not sure what cut).The giant robots that are carrying items in the stage are suppose to be a reference to the two CG 'movers' in the original Dire Straights music video.

https://youtu.be/lAD6Obi7Cag?t=89
https://youtu.be/zaWPTnHUEAY?t=343

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Why hasn't anyone ever attempted to port Snatcher to the SEGA 32X CD?
The SEGA CD version is great, especially with the added light gun support that the PC Engine CD version lacked.
However, the SEGA CD version has much less colours and has been graphically downgraded compared to the PC Engine CD version because the Genesis can output much less colours at a time compared to the PC Engine.
There's also the issue of minor censorship in the SEGA CD version.

Restoring the uncensored content is one thing, but it would be much harder to restore the higher colour depth of the PC Engine CD to the SEGA CD without having to port it to the 32X.

>>9483483
It's actually pretty massive, each of the final mixes in the kingdom hearts games adds more to sora's moveset, additional keyblades, and boss fights, but KH1 Final Mix is closer to a total rebalance.

KH1FM adds
-11 additional enemies, most notably neo shadow which is very iconic
-recolors most enemies to alternate color schemes (most people dislike this)
-a few more weapons for your characters
-more cutscenes
-a super duper final secret boss and accompanying ansem report
-gummi ship rebalanced to be harder
-really big one, more abilities are added to the three sets of skills that sora can learn and more variety between the three sets as far as what is learned and when. this means that the playstyles between attack, defense, and magic are much more distinct than in the original game

>>9487936

Some of the titles you chose brought my attention, so let me comment:

>SquareSoft Super Mario RPG 2

It would be nice to see a sequel on a N64. Same perspective and pre-rendered graphics but more resolution and animation frames.

>SquareSoft Legend of Zelda RPG

I wonder what advantages do you see the RPG level system bringing up to the tittle? Seems like an inferior LoZ to me.

>DK64 follow-up

I'd rather have a Donkey Kong Country sequel. Same perspective and pre-rendered stuff. 2-D pre-rendered graphics where so underused in that gen :-(

>BLOOD III

Nice, but where do you see this tittle going on from II? Personally I'd rather have some kind of remake of II, but yet in retro hardware.

>Super Mr. Gimmick

A port of that arcade Gimmick would be fine but more Gimmick is never too much.

My dream game is the unreleased Chakkan for Dreamcast. A Virtua Fighter III receiving the same treatment as Namco did for Soul Calibur would also be nice from Sega's part.

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Duke_Nukem_Forever

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

>>9485398
Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

>>9475092
Halo itself was a great series but its influence on the industry was pretty disastrous. Mainly it standardized dual stick + aim assist aiming for consoles which is awful because its designed to trick console players into thinking its not there, and it just aims for them. At the time it was the only solution that could have worked but now that both Sony and Nintendo have controllers that support dual stick + gyro aim, thats the far better way to aim in console shooters, debatably on par with KBM, but aim assist will never go away because console players are far too accustomed to it.

Ask any PC gamer what they think of console FPS and most of them disapprove solely because of the aim assist control scheme - something that console only casuls will never notice. And superior aim methods that are now possible will never take off because Halo caused one thing to be too well established.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9457750
It's the rotation rules ("Super Rotation System" is what it stands for) that The Tetris Company mandates, among other things that publishers who license Tetris must abide by to be given an official stamp of approval (referred to in whole as the "Tetris Guideline").

They're very nitpicky about this, even going so far as to decommission older Tetris games (like Game Boy Tetris) for retroactively not abiding by their ruleset.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Honestly given how stringent they are I'm surprised they still get involved with the Classic Tetris World Championships since NES Tetris definitely doesn't adhere to any modern interpretation of the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9483134
much appreciated, although after slaving away at these games for three years i'd consider myself mildly competent at best lol. it's been quite a while since i frequented ta.p
it's been long enough that i'm already starting to forget the things that helped me succeed so i'll just regurgitate the advice i usually give to people in your position:
>read tgm.tips, the tetris wiki, and old tetrisconcept threads like they're your personal bible (disc*rd is occasionally helpful if you're willing to use the fucking thing and can handle it responsibly)
>watch tgm superplays on youtube at 0.5x speed and analyze what each player does while trying to predict their next move - if they do something different, ask yourself why they made that decision and if it was the better play in hindsight. you can't think piece-by-piece, you have to consider how your stack is going to affect you in the long run
>grind 20g, do it in a clone like texmaster or with the 20g cheat. it sounds terrifying, but a common suggestion i saw was to grind death in tap until you can get used to the lower level speeds and i actually recommend that, if you can hit death 300 you can probably get tgm1 gm. ars seems scary until you realize it's restrictive enough there are only a few places you can put down a piece at any given time, which makes it easier to stack - 20g restricts your options further, it's mostly a matter of learning *how* to put the pieces where you want
>get used to abusing irs as much as you can
>i'm awful at not choking, but my advice: misdropping once is not the end of the world, look for downstacking opportunities and take them as soon as you can. 20g and death in particular will force you to git gud at this
>this isn't too relevant until you start time attacking, but avoid clearing singles since it wastes time
i can't fucking find when i did it but it took me at least 3 or 4 months to go from breaking level 500 to getting gm, keep chipping away at it and you'll get it soon enough

posts.com:

oh fuck, and in tgm1, stack as high as you can in the early game (0-300, you want to have a high stack at 200 specifically since the game resets to level 0 speeds there) and avoid overhangs as much as possible since you can't sonic drop and your early game will be insufferably slow otherwise. this only becomes really relevant once you start trying to improve your own time, but if you're actually having trouble hitting the 13:30 gm requirement or any of the torikans it's nice to keep in mind. i might have more worthless advice later but i'm about to pass out desu

>>9483917
ah shit. in that case, grinding death and shirase helped me improve my stacking speed to the point where tgm1 20g feels almost serene in comparison - granted, neither of those modes teach you how to stack cleanly for tetrises, but i think going for death m + 20g gm in tgm1 is a good goal to set if you're trying to break the 11 minute barrier, eventually 20g stacking will become second nature and you'll actually feel like you're in control most of the time
if you can, make recordings of your gameplay and analyze those too to see what you could have done here - there's a tc thread where people made fucking spreadsheets writing down all of their section times, line clears and level stops (https://tetrisconcept.net/threads/analyze-videos-of-your-gameplay.2821/) seeing what they could improve on. are you not making it under 11 minutes because you spent 15 seconds trying to clear a line on level 499? did you make way too many singles after level 500? it sounds boring as hell but it's a really good way of figuring out what you need to improve on. watch out for level stops in particular, they can really add up over the course of a run and there's no sound indicator for them until ti
also go watch 777's 8:49 wr from a decade ago and weep: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ZyBcWXrO4E

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487747
If it was just an overlay of lines, it'd be nothing.
But a proper shader is separating red, green, and blue signals for each pixel into separate phosphors, applying distortion onto the overall image, specific blending properties based on adjacent colors, etc. And all of this has to be done to every pixel on every rendered frame.
On top of the game being played in the first place, it's a lot.

>>9489031
As an oldfag who lived through this particular moment in time:

What people need to realize is that we were all used to games being kind of meh. Even the absolute best games of that era were still simplistic and repetitive, and licensed ones in particular were awful. Spider-Man was bad. Superman was bad. Raiders of the Lost Ark was...not exactly bad but weird and hard. E.T. also being meh was hardly a shock. Most new games were meh, and that was the real problem. It was less of a "that's it, this is the last straw" sort of thing and more of just a gradual loss of interest. E.T. being a killer app might have rejuvenated the market temporarily so it was a huge missed opportunity but the shit was already sinking. This didn't cause it, it just didn't help.

Also, I knew lots of people who bought the E.T. cartridge, and I don't know anyone who returned it. You tended to keep games unless they were completely unplayable. In this particular case the issue was that they assumed the name alone would move units and didn't actually wait to see if the demand manifested. E.T. was no worse than most of the shit Atari was shoveling, they just printed way more of this particular piece of shit than usual

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's not as popular now as it used to be, but it's still alive. Every version has at least one private server.

Most populated servers for each version:
Dreamcast: Sylverant https://sylverant.net
Gamecube: Schthack https://schtserv.com
Xbox: Schthack https://schtserv.com
PC: Ephinea https://ephinea.pioneer2.net

Gamecube and Xbox are similar enough to crossplay, and they just got it working mere weeks ago. But Dreamcast and PC versions are too different from the others for crossplay to work.

PC is the most popular version these days, and in some ways the best one, as it's the only one with Episode 4.

If you want to play on a console, I'd recommend the Gamecube version on a Wii. Dreamcast is missing Episode 2. Getting ethernet hardware for either Dreamcast or Gamecube is expensive. Cheaper on an Xbox obviously, but that's still a little glitchy - I see Xbox players disconnecting a lot.

Wii is cheap and easy to hack (https://wii.guide), only requires a USB adapter for ethernet, which you can find for $10 on Ebay (although make sure you get the right one). Once you have that, the homebrew app Nintendont will load the game and emulate the Broadband Adapter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473260
Absolutely. Especially if you can get friends in on the splitscreen multiplayer. One of the things that impressed me most about PSO on GCN is that everyone can have their own characters on their own memory cards, and are completely independent. If you start a party with friends in FF Crystal Chronicles, your character is stuck in that party. In PSO though, you can play with one group of friends one day, and then take your memory card and use the same character with a completely different group of friends the next day. 4 players can play together with 4 different characters on 4 different memory cards, even though the gamecube only has 2 memory card ports.

One caveat though; the camera sucks in split screen. Don't jump straight into multiplayer with four level 1 characters. Everyone should play a bit of single player first to get used to playing the game before their screen gets shrunk down to one-quarter of the screen. And to get some money for restocking healing items.

He would connect Diablo to the network and play until morning, wake up to work, and then play again. Some of us weren’t going home much at the time. Some people would go home just to bathe, sleep a few hours, come back into the office to work, and then play Diablo at the office. It was mostly in the name of research, though. There are a number of games that we used as inspiration. Diablo was obviously one of them. I had heard that Dragon Quest was inspired by remaking Ultima with a Japanese audience in mind. So our concept was, “Let’s make a Diablo game that would appeal to the Japanese audience.”

>Interviewer: With good results. Even though Diablo is a distinctly American game, PSO feels like a very distinctly Japanese game. And yet, it’s not just palatable to Japanese gamers but to everyone.
>I think Diablo is an amazing game, but it’s not a game that appeals to Japanese players. Our suspicion was that Japanese gamers would prefer to cooperate and work together to defeat something more than to compete and fight against other players. That’s why we created PSO to be a cooperative role-playing game. Diablo has cooperative elements but it also has PK and an element of killing other player characters. We eliminated those elements and focused on how we could make a fun, cooperative RPG experience. I think that’s the biggest difference between PSO and Diablo.

I was pretty stupid when I first played PSO. I loved the aesthetics, the world was super cool, and teaming up with my friends to play together was great. I remember all of us getting set up on PC and when all of us were there, we played through either a space station (tutorial?) or the area shown here >>9471891 and it was a fun time until the leader of our party suggested we play the same dungeon again. Then again, and again. I recall we had played the same area for around 2 hours before I asked if we could move on, to which the party leader said we weren't really ready for the next area and that we'd need to go through a few more times. It was the first time I can remember experiencing grinding in a video game.

I remember playing on my own after, and making it easily through the next area, but I didn't have experience with these types of games, nor did I really get the whole dungeon-looting loop since I had mostly played linear games that didn't require grinding before that. I fell off, sadly, but I'll always appreciate the atmosphere this series set up with its cool designs, great music, etc. I gave PSU a shot when that came out, I think in a demo version, and it somehow landed with me more than PSO did at the time, but I think it's just simply because I wasn't as stupid with game genres anymore. Maybe I should try PSO again sometime.

>>9481298
>There's barely any platforming

What is WITH everyone and their mother calling B-K and 3D platformer, it is NOT A PLATFORMER. A 3D platformer is fucking Glover or Mario 64. Banjo DOES have mini-platforming IN it, sparsely, as a vehicle for getting across the map. That doesn't make it a platformer any more than Zelda is a "3D platformer" just for having vague platform shit in it at times. Platforming is NOT a major focus in Banjo, and you can tell this because one of the few sections of the game that IS like a 3D platformer, the Engine Room, sticks out like a huge sore thumb against everything else in the game. The kind of platforming you use to traverse from A to B is not a major focus of the game.

Now it still is totally a fair critique to say that Banjo doesn't control anywhere near as nimble and complex as Mario can, which sucks and is lame. I wish his movement options were better, the game would be way more fun. But they also design Banjo-Kazooie AROUND the fact that the bear is stiff and doesn't do much. The focus is NOT platforming, it's not even trying to be. Banjo is an adventure-exploration collectathon, with minor elements of 3D platforming and puzzle-solving. It is extremely rare for tough platforming to be a focus because asking this clunky-ass bear to do acrobatic feats is not generally feasible. He is NOT Mario. Banjo is a slower
more methodical game based on exploration and bite-sized task completion.

I don't know why you would even bring up the fact that Gobi's Valley's pyramids lack much in the way of platforming. That literally is not at all the point of this game. It's only surface-level similar to Mario, it's not structured the same way at all. Deliberately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
ive made some repros before the age of cheap flashcarts, its not hard just a bunch of steps and its easier to just get a flash cart and you dont have to kill another NES game


--Repro--
>patch rom/download rom
>split rom in an emulator
>find cart with same mapper/board of the rom
>open cart
>de-solder chr and prg chips
> find compatible blank eprom
>aquire eprom programmer
>burn chr rom (pad the rom file if need be)
>burn prg rom (pad the rom file if need be)
>solder chips
>cover eprom window
>re assemble cart
>hope it works

--Flash cart--
>download rom
>put rom in cart
>play

>>9485479
It's late 1999 and the other consoles out at the time are the PS1, N64, and Saturn. Games on all of these systems either ran like crap and/or looked like crap. If you had a Dreamcast from this period to when it got canned in early 2001 you had a system that had the best looking, most action packed games at the time on top of running silky smooth. Oh, and great 4 player games that didn't require a multitap or ran at 5 frames a second. It feels sorta underwhelming today and nothing special, like the original SMB or Half Life, but put your head in the mindset of gamers at the time and you'll see that there was literally nothing like it and understand why it was so appreciated.

The concept was that there are 3 intake fans from the front, so to match 2 fans to pull the air up and to the rear. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464565
Prototyping ASICs. That's basically the reason they were invented.
Aviation and automation. It's cheaper in the long run to run the onboard software on an FPGA simulated ASIC than an actual ASIC because when some new bullshit law comes in that demands your component respond 0.0001% faster you can just update the hardware with new HDL at a routine service, rather than expensive downtime at a factory where somebody has to literally take it apart and solder a new chip on, and you don't have an expensive new ASIC run to produce.
Military. Same deal. Any hardware flaws can be fixed in the field, you don't have to say "sorry Vlad, can we postpone the war, we're upgrading our nukes to Ryzen."

>>9467459
>I'm still not sure what this thing is
You're familiar with the term FPGA, in a loose fashion, yeah? MiSTer is a project that is taking advantage of a cheap FPGA that people can buy, called the DE-10 Nano. The DE-10 Nano is cheap because it is made for college students, and is subsidized by Intel. The DE-10 Nano has an FGPA on board, as well as an ARM chip. It has various connectors on the board for expandability. MiSTer has a bunch of FPGA cores (much like the cores you would see on one of the Analog systems) for consoles, handhelds, arcade boards and computers. Developers are constantly adding more cores and improving on existing cores. A hobbiest community has popped up around this project, which has led to a lot of hardware addons that can be installed onto the DE-10 Nano, such as extra RAM, a digital or analog I/O board, USB hub (these things make up the most common MiSTer setup that you have likely seen, which is a sandwich of three boards with the DE-10 Nano in the middle)... etc. There are people who have made specialized expansion boards like the MiSTercade, which allows it to be used in a typical JAMMA arcade cabinet. At a base level, you really just need the DE-10 Nano, and preferably a RAM stick, the rest is optional.

MiSTer can be appealing to enthusiasts because it offers better accuracy/latency compared to software emulation. It's also very easy to set up and use in a variety of scenarios, without having to invest in a bunch of extra shit like flash carts, upscalers, custom cables... etc. It is an all-in-one solution for many of the systems that a retro gamer would be interested in. By its nature, it is also very customizable.

I still think that software emulation is a good option, especially on a budget since you can probably do it on hardware that you already own, however I do like my MiSTer quite a bit and I find that I am playing more /vr/ games than ever since getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the perfect middle ground. You've got original hardware accurate latency, perfect audio timing, ease of use with a CRT and compatibility with a number of peripherals, tied with loading roms, save states for some cores, using any controller you want, and emulation perks like CPU overclocking for SNES.

If you're into collecting and playing carts, then go real hardware. But if you were just going to buy flash carts for all of your systems, I don't see any reason not to just go the mister route. You're getting the same console quality experience. And you don't have to worry about shit like HDMI mods for your hardware, or upscalers like the retrotink if you want to hook it up to a modern TV, it has all that built in. You don't have to worry about RGB modding hardware to get the most clarity, it's all just built in.

I think it's a really nifty option and I have no clue why /vr/ shits themselves over it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464069
Runahead latency isn't accurate. FPGA is latency accurate, in that a good core can reasonably achieve identical latency to original hardware.

Additionally the overhead to achieve accurate latency is much easier. Software emulators generally try for timing accuracy or cycle accuracy with a lot of optimization and tricks required to do so. With FPGA once you've defined the logic it mostly just works how you'd expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464110
With FPGA the actual video circuit of the recreated system directly drives the raster of the CRT, just like the original hardware could. You will always have a framebuffer on PC, always some abstraction away from native interf
aces.

That looks like a cheap scaled-down version of Sanni's cart reader, you can build your own if you are handy with a soldering iron, or you can find some place that has the latest (version 5) pre-built.

https://github.com/sanni/cartreader/

The latest version (If you build the model with all 7 cartridge connectors) does NES, Famicom, SNES, Sega Master System, Sega Genesis, Sega CD RAM carts, N64, GB, GBC, and GBA.

There are adapters to also make it work with TG16, Wonderswan, Game Gear, Neo Geo Pocket, Intellivision, Colecovision, and a dozen or so other systems.

Everyone says "GTA3", but it wasn't exactly so dark/edgy. It had violence, adult themes and muted colors, not edgy goth teens.
Moreover, remember the PS2 ads. They already were edgy as hell.
I think what happened was just general paradigm shift that occurred through late 90s, when games stopped pandering to mostly children under 13 and instead started targeting people 14 and up. GTA3 and Halo were key in signaling this moment though, but even before that it became clear that it's not only bing bang wahoo games that sold big, with games like THPS showing that something that teens liked, with music and subculture, could sell well.
At the same time, obviously, it was a time of darkness and edginess in music and media. It started with grunge, but became more and more mainstream with time, as acts like Marylin Manson, Slipknot, etc. reached wide appeal.
These 2 things were a direct change from 1980–early '90s—instead of bright colors, playful, almost childlike looks in everything, the pendulum swung to gritty, grungy, aggressive stuff. Video games especially got stuck in this for a bit too long, when most Sega / Nintendo games were obviously bright and cheerful.
So all of this resulted in companies chasing the new trend of edginess, making endless goth characters with twisted cycle path personalities, and things like that.

I hate this fallacy of "modern things are just as good, they are just different".
First of all—no, it's not at all an absolute truth. Culture can get better or worse. And no, it doesn't necessarily always get better.
Two—yes, media is splintered. But that's the problem. By doing this, Internet indirectly destroyed the best media that we had and replaced it with a void of people with a lot of voice but no ideas.
To elaborate, let me make a simple model.
There's "lower class" of media. These are standalone artists, lone enthusiasts, small groups of people with little to no funding. Today, these are sole youtubers / tiktokers / soundcloud rappers / etc. In old vidya, these were the people who made old computer games with basic graphics, Flash games, etc.; today, these are indie / phone game devs. Pros of this class can be freedom of experimentation, enthusiasm, and full creative control; the cons can be lack of budget to implement ideas, often lackluster / flawed quality, incredible proneness to shovelware, and last but not least, lack of educated professionals who actually went to school to study art and aren't just some random meme fucks.
Then there's the "upper class". This is your EA, Activision, Nintendo, you get the drill. These are your big movie studios, your music labels, your TV companies, etc. Pros: big budgets to make things more impressive, implement ideas, hire professional artists / game designers / directors / etc., and ensure at least decent quality. Cons: the cons are often lack of freedom and creative control, resulting in "soulless" feel and rehashing same ideas. So—it's like a polar opposite of the "lower class".
But then there's the "middle class"—The golden middle where you could argue you get the best of both worlds and where some of the best pieces of media were conceived. This is where you have money, enough to make quality things and implement ideas, but not too much so that you can take artistic risk.

(2/3)
Of course, "middle class" is very relative, but it's that vague middle ground between EA and sole devs, Taylor Swift and soundcloud rappers, Avengers and some youtube video, etc.
You could argue that in vidya, these perfect conditions were achieved during late '80s–early '90s. When the hardware naturally limited budgets and what could be achieved, most companies weren't too big, smaller companies like Id could give full creative control to a bunch of dudes to make Doom or Quake—just think how many great games still talked about today came out on PC at around 2000. In music, this was the time when rock bands could have time and budget to devote themselves to music fully, and when musicians actually could play instruments. In movies, this was the time before blockbusters completely took over.
So, where am I going with all of this? In modern day, "middle class" of media has eroded. You either have lower class that gets always smaller, and upper class that gets ever bigger, to the point when it's "too big to fail". Today, by and large, you either get EA OR phone / indie devs, Taylor Swift OR soundcloud rappers, Avengers OR some youtube video, etc. It either has budget under $100k, or budget over $100 mln. But ironically—both sides are actually stretched thin and can have low profits.
How that happened? First off, the Internet. Downloading destroyed the music record industry. From year 2000 to 2010, it has shrunk 4 times for the first time in recent history after decades of growth. Like you said already, it has made a lot of other media irrelevant too. It has destroyed print media, it made TV networks less relevant each year.
Second, most relevant to vidya—advancement of computers. Better graphics every year meant bigger budgets every year. Games went from costing under 1 mln to develop to $100+ mln. Vidya studios went from 10-20 guys to whole sweatshops of hundreds of people working for years.

The phones have already killed handhelds. Even Ninty had to take note. Meanwhile, the phone market is, again, oversaturated with garbage. The competition is insane, the profits are lowering.
Now what's worse—those from the "lower class" who got rich are actually buying or replacing the upper class and "traditional" media. Chinese mobile companies are buying off big Western devs. You have a fucking Cartoon Cat TV shows for kids now. Soundcloud rappers get their trademark meals in McDs.
And looking at "upper class", you can see where the $100+ mln budgets are taking us. I think we have 2 great recent examples: Cyberpunk 2077, and Justice League. Both cost $300+mln. Both were considered big failures upon release.
So I could go on and on. But you get the picture. The death of "middle class" of media has had huge consequences on everything.

On the topic of the net and on free shit, it is to me like the dark age of cartoons. This is an era often identified by cartoon historians as the period from early 1960s until early 1980s or so. The idea is that the big picture companies stopped making shorts, so then the animators had nowhere to go. Cartoons were dead in the water except for Disney, so unless you worked for Disney you had to go to whomever picked up the slack, which was TV. However, the budgets for TV were tiny compared to the budget for shorts, and so the resulting product was hampered. What`s more, TV networks wanted very generic and repetitive material and were very risk-averse. If a winner was found, they wanted the same winner, over and over again. These two factors are why Hannah-Barbara made so many identical, low-budget shows in this time period; It was all that the networks would buy. This is why you had so many clone shows of Scooby-Doo after that was a big hit, to say nothing of spinoff series. The era ended once toy companies came in and injected money to make toy sales happen, which led to animators getting encouraged financially to stop making shit (though unfortunately much of it was outsourced to low-grade sweatshop animators, at least they started trying again).

I have long suspected that we are in a repeat of that era, especially given how sad the output of the cartoon cable channels have been in the new millennium. The market is moving/has moved again, whether to free platforms like youtube or to online paid services. But for the former, there`s no money again, and so we are in a repeat of that dark era. You need money to get good shit, that`s the truth.

What you pointed out about media bombs is not new, however. There have been overbudget flops in hollywood for decades. Just off the top of my head is Waterworld, and it`s hardly the only example. Your argument that only now do we have mega-bombs that waste hundreds of millions is simply not rooted in truth.

On the subject of media, I think I will risk making a fool of myself by discussing society at large, and say that to me, media feels safe and connections feel disingenuous because it is a model of society. Art imitates life, they say, and when every person can access every and any thing, and when there is absolutely no gatekeeping of information or of ideas by any measure, then it basically becomes possible for anyone to live in any world that they want to live in, no matter what it is. A remember a sociologist predicting in the 80s that innovations like e-mail and automatic remote garage openers would lead to people becoming more and more isolated from each other, to the point that they wouldn`t even know their own neighbors. I would argue that his worst fears are even more true than he could have realized at the time.

I think the irony is that we tech nerds that were largely the test model for this kind of human. Whether it is the 80s or the 2000s, computer junkies were the beta test of the modern day disconnected human; Who else can more exhibit the colors of a digitally wired, physically detached person than those of us who have been shitting online for decades? Stuck to a screen, casually destroying people we have never met nor seen in person for transgressions we have often arbitrarily determined from some pathetically small infraction, who among us can look at twitter warriors and such ilk and not see their own shit-eating teenage grin smirking back at them, reveling in the epic burn served to some stupid faggot in a forum post, the angry email sent to some focus of aggression?

>These 2 things were a direct change from 1980–early '90s—instead of bright colors, playful, almost childlike looks in everything, the pendulum swung to gritty, grungy, aggressive stuff
I think this needs some elaboration on.
in the 80s (which extended to the 90s), the zeitgeist was about bright, playful stuff, that was deliberately un-serious. this wasn't an accident.
the decade prior saw the rise of modernism in the world. modernism is the kind of design most exemplified like identical glass skyscrapers, stuff made of raw materials like glass, steel, and concrete (which was later ripped off by Apple products and stores), and minimalism with lots if Helvetica. the main complaint about it was that it was too serious, bland, and boring. so what happened?
naturally, in the West at least, zeitgeist changes feel very much like pendulum swings. often any "movement" starts as a rejection of the old, deliberately going in entirely opposite direction, with a few key visionaries paving the way. this becomes the "new thing", while making the old zeitgeist feel "yesterday". quickly, artists and media catch up to the trend, milk it while it's hot, and try to one up each other by pushing the pendulum even further. this naturally makes everything reach a new extreme, which often comes out quite trashy as result. people get sick of it, rejection starts, rinse wash repeat.
so this is what happened in the 80s. the 70s modernism was too serious, bland, and boring. enter 80s that was un-serious, playful, bright, cheesy, colorful, and fun. neon spandex, Duran Duran, Miami Vice, hair metal, "have fun bro" attitude.
This naturally carried to vidya, too. It was natural that "kids love bright colors", and 8 & 16-bit hardware naturally had color limitations, so that's why this exuberant look stuck for quite long. Btw, 90s Nickelodeon was sort of an extension of that.
(1/2)

This happened before too, the best example being how it got reflected in 1940s comic books. In the early 40s, comic books were load and flashy and aggressive, full of colorful superheroes murdering nazis. Then the war ended, people wanted to put it behind them, and this kind of violent punchy action stuff felt a lot less appealing. Audiences wanted lighthearted and inoffensive fun, and comedic light drama like Archie took over for the superheroes. Then the pendulum started swinging the other way and audiences wanted more realistic and "edgy" stuff - not superheroes, which were always really fantastic and larger than life, but gritty and brutal crime and horror, as well as war comics that showed the dirty reality of war instead of glorifying it and shitting on the enemy.

What your typical rando thought of when he heard the phrase "comic book" in the early 40s was Captain America, in the late 40s it was Archie, and in the early 50s it was Crime Does Not Pay. Three very very different books that had extreme mass appeal during their respective biggest eras.

I don't think this because of my own experiences, but because of that from older people who I have read from or talked to about it.
