I will say though, that to me, the social media world did turn things a different way, and I think it is for two reasons. The first is as in that consolidation pic; Everybody is in the same place. It's like when /v/irgins complained about the death of custom servers and the rise of P2P; You used to be able to choose your own experience in a given online game, and with P2P all the casual players, tryhards, dumb stoners, people with contrasting opinions, etc. were forced into one player pool and robbed of their choice to not be a part of it. I think social media has largely done the same thing. Anything you put on Twitter, for example, can be found and exploited at any time by any number of thousands of people in some tiny internet cabal that no one's ever heard of, and make your life hell over it. Pretty hard to do that if everyone is on different websites.

The second reason is that point above, which is that the stakes are higher. When I started using 4chan, the internet was SERIOUS BIZNESS, because we laughed at anyone taking shit seriously on the internet. There are still trappings of that mentality in places like /s4s/, but by and large the rule has changed. People across the net now take it very seriously and even stake their work and livelihood on it. The threat is real when people can legitimately ruin your life over a post.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9488362
Incidentally, the other problem with doing everything through online posts is that posts don't go away. I remember reading a soft skills book that said the absolute worst thing you can do is try to send an important message, especially an emotional one, through text in any form. This focused in some respect on work email, but covered text arguments or anything else. The reason is that voices are evanescent and they disappear with time, fading from existence. Words, however (as well as video and audio recordings), can be copied and viewed infinitely, over and over again, and most importantly, reading words that make you angry feels like you are reading them for the first time freshly stated out of the person's mouth, no matter how old the words actually are. This, I have seen, is how shitstorms brew. When your words are not thin as air, floating away, but instead are heavy waves, pounding and pounding on mental shores with the dedicated repetition of the ocean tide, it doesn't give people time to heal from whatever anger they may have gotten out of it. Moreover, it doesn't give time for change. I remember once reading about the ancient Greeks and their opposition to the invention of writing. Their main opposition was that you would write something down, and then your mind would change, but your words would not.

The SNES and the Genesis pulled about equal numbers in the North American market but that is with Sega shifting support from the Genesis to the Saturn in 94 giving the SNES 95 and 96 almost unopposed. From 91 when the Sega Genesis actually started selling in large volumes up until 94 Sega had a significant lead in the North American market. In Europe the situation was even worse for Nintendo and they never caught up at all even after Sega moved on. So often when a game was made in the west it was made with Genesis in mind and then ported to SNES. In Japan the Genesis was a footnote so in the rarer case when a game was made for both consoles it was usually SNES first and a port to Genesis to grab money from the western market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: That Motorolla 68000 CPU in the Genesis/ Mega Drive was a big factor in it, because many of the 16bit micro computers like the Amiga, Atari ST and Macintosh all used 16/32bit variants of that CPU. EA was primarily a PC developer before they got into the home market with the Genesis. They avoided the NES because they didn't want to be locked into a Nintendo contract. They thought the hardware was old and outdated by 1990. They used their knowledge of the 68000 CPU to reverse engineer the Genesis and make their own dev kits, and used that as a bargaining ship to get a good third party deal with Sega. Which worked., A lot of developers who came from the Amiga and Atari ST were just really familiar with the Motorolla 68000 CPU. The founder of Travellers Tales Jon Burton was an Amiga demo-scener before breaking into the console market on the Mega Drive. Also the 68000 CPU was used in a lot of 16bit arcade machines. Really common CPU for the time. It's not like the SNES was hard to use in comparison, as it uses a 16bit variant on the 6502 CPU found in the NES. Apple used this CPU in their Apple IIGS system, and the Apple II GS was also used as a dev kit for the SNES. The SNES is really not a CPU driven system, and I think everything was mostly handled by the GPU instead.

>>9476704
>last bronx imho

Most of the best 3D fighters on the Saturn came from Sega.

- Virtua Fighter (Launch game/ pack-in game)
- Virtua Fighter Remix (given away as free at times)
- Virtua Fighter 2 (arguably one of the best 3D fighters on the console)
- Virtua Fighter Kids (it's Virtua Fighter 2 with big headed 'kid' characters. The gameplay is different from of the different strike ranges.
- Fighting Vipers - It's a defensive styled game that revolves around body armor. The areas are walled too. You can intentionally break off your armour to move faster.
- Fighters MegaMix - Virtua Fighter 2 characters with partial VF3 moves list, vs Fighting Vipers. With other AM2 guest characters.
- Last Bronx - weapon based fighting game, it also has an anime vibe to it.
- Virtual On : This is a bit more like an arena combat game.

Non Sega 3D Fighters:
- Dead or Alive - Japanese only release
- Final Fight Revenge - This one is also a Japan only release and requires the 4MB RAM cart.
- Battle Arena Toshinden -port of the PS1 game
- Battle Arena Toshinden URA - better than the first one
- D-Xhird - weapon based fighter with enclosed arenas
- Criticom
- Rise 2: Resurrection - sequel to Rise of the Robots. It sucks.
- FIST (Japanese only 3D fighter)


The Saturn's third party line up of 3D fighters is a bit hit or miss. But the first party 3D fighters were generally all good IMO. The Saturn has a much bigger selection of third party 2D fighters. Overall, the Saturn was great for fighting games.

The DOA2 was developed using NAOMI hardware, which is basically the arcade version of the Dreamcast hardware with more memory, the DC game does look close to the arcade game, with slightly lower resolution textures and a few other differences. But, 480p via VGA, the game was one of the best looking 3D fighters on the DC outside of Soul Calibur. The Dreamcast also got a limited edition version that was released only in Japan, which included the extras found in the PS2 game.

>>9485062
>It couldn't do progressive 480p scan (the reason why DoA2 looks better on Dreamcast) but then it suddenly could with Tekken 5 and Gran Turismo 4.

It could do 480p, but then you were left with almost no VRAM left. Most programmers at the time expected VRAM to hold both textures and framebuffer, so they went for small framebuffer and crap textures with 4 colors.

Then years later they figured out they can write a code on the coprocessor that textured from system memory (where they had a massive lead), because the vram was so stupid fast that this was actually practical. After that you had 480p games.

for me if it has:
-widescreen standard
-HDMI or 720p standard
-internet heavily integrated and using it is expected rather than a maybe
-wireless controllers standard made by the system manufacturer and not exclusive to a third-party peripheral or a little-used add-on or side product
-any kind of network-based anti-piracy or security feature (including software license keys)
-DVD or higher capacity disks as standard

Then it is probably not retro.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Basically when games and technology started specifically aiming for a photorealistic picture, is when "retro" truly ended. To me what we call retro - both 2D and early 3D - is not about dates but rather about artistic merits of working around major technical limitations, which is what made those games so good. When every game looked absolutely different and unique because they were all hyper-stylized artistic depictions of reality seen through the prism of artistry of creative people. Not so much anymore when 90% of the entire development process goes towards making everything look how it does in real life - which is, you know, the same. When the 7th gen started we didn't just gain things like upgrades in storage space and resolution, for the first time in history we started progressively losing things, losing artistry, because there were no more major technical limitations to overcome. More and more elements started becoming token. So much so that we saw the rise of tertiary elements like online becoming more popular than the games themselves.

Their hardware angle was set and leaned into, their policy and strategy on the brave new werld of microtransactions, unfinished beta AAA releases, bloatgramming, and various other consumer abuses that old games lack were set and normalized.

Maybe retro can be defined by exactly in which ways companies abused consumers. Back in the day your lives were tied to a real life quarter that you popped into the machine, so the market wanted HARD games that you learned to play by dying repetitively. >Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

A new generations model, not based on years, but on hardware and gameplay:
1 - Pre-NES.
2 - NES-TG16-SMS.
3 - SNES-SMD-GB-PS1.
4 - PS1-N64-SAT.
5 - PS2-Wii era, incl. GBA and DS.
6 - PS3-360-WiiU era, incl. 3ds.
7 - Xbone-PS4 thru today.
Nintendo since Wii has dropped a generation behind the pack. I think the major problem with the previous model was basing it off of Nintendo's consoles as if they represented the pack, when really they are notable outliers. Look at them today especially, their main system is a handheld! To say the switch is the representative of modern gaming isn't entirely accurate, it more represents the previous generation's staying power.
Look at human beings. There are 4 or 5 generations living today. They are each different, but one's inception is not necessarily the other's demise. a generation lasts as long as it is able to compete for market space. 8bit did it for a whole decade on a puny B&W screen, but it stuck it out!

Games should be categorized based on the types of technology used, not arbitrary release dates. Similarly, Jazz music will never become classical. Its dumb to call an 8 bit hand held a later gen just because it came out later. The gamegear is literally just a master system. The Wii is literally just an overclocked gamecube and has a weaker CPU & GPU than the Xbox. Using this logic, here's the REAL gaming eras:

Pre-Retro Era:
Gen 1 - Literally just Pong
Gen 2 - Atari 2600, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about

[Insert Gaming Crash Here]

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii
Gen 6.5 (High Poly, but low resolution) - Xbox

[Insert Globohomo Here]

Modern Era (HD widescreen, Microtransactions, Day 1 patches, hyper realism, Casualization, homogenized controllers, homogenized architecture, mocap, facescan, Californian management, etc...):
Gen 7 (Early HD) - 360, PS3, Vita, Wii U, Switch
Gen 8 (Gen 7 + Stable 1080p) - PS4, Xbone
Gen 8.5 (Gen 7 + 4K) - PS4 Pro, Xbone X
Gen 9 (Gen 7 + 4K + RTX) - PS5, Xbox SX

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487456
the game isn't uninspired. it's pretty fun and quirky. it's definitely not a system seller or mario killer, but it's a pretty solid platformer. i'm not trying to say it's an amazing game everyone should play, but i do believe the game is pretty fun if you do approach it with the right expectations. the game has a lot of old school game design chinese trickery where you sort of have to put yourself in the mind of the developer and try to figure out what traps and pitfalls is set out for you, instead of rushing forward guns blazing. it is that sort of game that dangles an item box down a corridor in a suspicious maner, and you just know some trap is gonna befal you if you go there. i do like that sort of game, provided it isn't too cryptic to figure out or unfair, it's pretty balanced in its approach, you just need to pay attention and just keep in your mind a chinese man programming the game with an evil grim trying to figure out ways to trick you. eventually you figure out the game is all about buying the right items and use them at the right time, instead of trying to do everything with your vanilla moveset, that way you will burn out all your lives unless you're the gamemaster. janken is just a weird quirk of the game, they were experimenting with something goofy, turns out it's not a good idea. either way it's not a big deal, the janken isn't actually random, they do all the same moves provided you don't die, so just take a note of what the right moves are in order and do them next time you play. even though is obviously an RNG dumb mechanic it still plays well with the childish demeaner of the game. in 3 or 4 playthroughs you can beat the game, it isn't hard.

OoT's FPS is actually kind of a weird situation, it only renders graphics at 20fps but the game logic actually runs at 60fps (each visual frame is repeated 3 times) and it accepts inputs at 60fps. It's weird to wrap your head around, but it makes it play WAY better than it would if it was actually running at 20fps.

>>9486861
Those elementary guesses are about all you get though. Compare the forest temple to the big house in the sky from SM64. There's ultimately nothing to the Mario house. You can write all the fanfictions you want about who the owner is and why they live in the sky, but ultimately the game doesn't supply you with anything.

The forest template obviously has a bit more character than the Mario house, but they ultimately have the same purpose: a big building with a mcguffin inside. No NPCs will tell you anything about who used to live there. Neither of them have so much as a bedroom or a kitchen. It's not a big deal for Super Mario, which cares famously little about plot, but OoT really does try to flesh out its world, so I wish it had given the temples more substance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anons like >>9484694 are right, Sega's home consoles never were big in Japan to begin with.
Genesis sold ~17 mln units in America, while in Japan it only managed 3.58 mln—when Super Famicom sold 17 mln. Sega wasn't even a 2nd biggest player in Japan, as PC-Engine outsold it.
Then was Saturn, it sold ~5 mln units in Japan, was actually Sega's best-selling console there, but guess what—Sega did a fucky wucky, and never made a real Sonic game for it anyway. Plus, PSX still outsold it hard, its total was 22 mln units. And DC flopped quick anyway, it was too little too late for it to make Sonic big.
Sega was big in the arcades, but like other anons have said, Sega never made a proper arcade Sonic.
So no, it likely has nothing to do with "furry" characters or whatever. Especially when you remember that DKC and Crash series sold a fuckton in Japan. Fun fact: DKC3 actually sold more copies in Japan than in US.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9481589
Games needed to include drivers for the HDD to utilize it, and if every developer was ordered to put in HDD support for saving and loading, they'd probably also use it for caching, and maybe other exclusive features, and it could've reached a point where not having the HDD significantly crippled your enjoyment of PS2 games; they'd have to start bundling it with every console, making the console more expensive to manufacture and distribute.
Or in short, the HDD made things more expensive and complicated, so they didn't really want to promote it for more than the handful of games that required it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9481063
>>9481873
Sega's devs were more interested in supporting GameCube early on because they were bitter about PS2's part in killing the Dreamcast. More practically, PS2 was weaker in certain areas that made porting Dreamcast games to it difficult and required compromises. GameCube wasn't free of this either, but it tended to be less drastic.
PSO's devs probably wanted to focus on one version of the game and one player base for it, at least for a start. And they were already working on new content for Dreamcast they could no longer release on it, so they had to jump ship somewhere, and PC would've filtered out a lot of people, so it had to be another console. Dreamcast's dead, you hate PS2, Xbox doesn't exist yet...it has to be GameCube.

>>9481442
>Have you ever noticed that the Turbografx is actually just a black PC Engine with a big tumor attached to its left and rear sides?
Funny enough that redesign may have actually killed the console. NEC was targeting a Christmas 88 release but the sentiment that >>9483082 America needs a bigger device pushed them redesign the console, they took 7 months to design, prototype, produce and ship the new console, by the time they arrived for sale in summer of 89 the folks at Sega had already launched their Genesis system in America 2 weeks in advance and planned an aggressive ad campaign to claiming the TG16 was weak in comparison to the Genesis. Since PCe was already big in Japan and beating Sega there they pre-assumed victory and skimped on heavy marketing of the TG16 in favor of over production to meet a non-existent demand. That meant shelves full of unsold TG16's and people asking when the new Sega would be in stock... if they had the most powerful system on the market for 7 months, getting in peoples homes, spreading via word of mouth well, maybe the big rivalry of the 90's would be Nintendo vs NEC and not Sega.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9488036
FFC's requirements for RF shielding were written way before gaming consoles were even a concept and were originally intended for actual broadcasting equipment like radios. Since most gaming machines contained an RF modulator inside them, they had to obey to those specs. Before 1980s the specs were absolutely draconian and multiple 1970s consoles and computers had to be delayed for months because FCC thought that they didn't have enough metal around all electronics. These requirements were later greatly reduced, which in turn led to a many new machines being released in early 1980s. By the 1990s it was pretty much agreed that FCC's fears were based on outdated research.

Says the moron who still refuses to actually play it. Let's read what other people have to say, shall we?

>I prefer the PS1 version in my opinion. It has better controls, the PS1 graphics look great, it has an awesome soundtrack, and I heard it's superior version of the game. It's a really fun Toy Story game it's actually my first PS1 game.

>I have now started playing it on Dreamcast and I am a bit shocked by the analog controls. Basically, the controls work like dpad controls and the analog stick is mapped to the eight directions of a d-pad. This is not too unusual for games originating on PS1 back then, but what is unusual, and also insane, is the fact that the mapping seems to work like this: pick a very small epsilon and then determine for each of the four base directions, if they are pressed like this: if stickdirectionX > epsilon then right = true; if stickdirectionY > epsilon then forward = true (and similar for the opposite directions). As a consequence, if you only slightly deviate from the four base directions, you end up with a diagonal direction. This makes the game near unplayable with the analogstick and everytime I need even a bit of precision, I need to resort to the dpad.

Stop talking out your ass and actually fucking play the game. The Dreamcast version controls like absolute dogshit with the analog stick. Why are you defending a game you haven't even played?

>>9486597
Rather than comparing it to other Zelda games, you should compare it to other games on the system.
The Game Boy was perceived as a system for casual gamers who just wanted to play simple little time wasters like Tetris and not much else, but games like Link's Awakening went on to prove that it's capable of hosting some powerhouse games that are lengthy, adventurous, and can easily stand up to the big boys on console.
The game predates the first Pokémon games by three years, and yet look how much more polished it is. The game is a technical marvel, and as a bonus, for a Zelda game, it probably tells the most coherent and emotional narrative in the series up to that point. The game deserves all the praise it gets and more.

Depends on the game/system you're emulating.
But MAME is the best option obviously.
Although to make it arcade friendly you have to run it through a frontend and make it look like a real arcade you have to remove the shitty nag screens.

BigBlueFrontend on youtube sometimes makes No-Nag Screen builds.

Additionally, to have a good emulation experience you need a beefy CPU to run high frame-delay settings and you have to configure Windows to only run MAME and using ASIO for zero-audio latency.

It's a lot of work but it is doable.

>>9484740
I don't know if this is due to localization, but I always found Kefka's characterization post-WoR to be a bit weird. For most of the game he's a gleeful, sadistic psychopath who delights in making others suffer before ultimately killing them. His willing, knowing destruction of the world aligns with this, even if it appears to have been done on a whim. Now he has ultimate power to make the world an utterly miserable place for everyone, and he can kill and destroy anything and anyone with but a thought. But when you go to face him, he starts with brooding nihilistic shit he never brought up before, about how clinging to life is stupid if people know they're ultimately gonna die, etc. Then your party gives their reasons for going on living, and the mask comes off and he's back to having fun with taking "precious lives", but not before stating his ultimate objective is to just outright destroy everything, which would leave him without purpose or lives to end for his amusement. So, what's his deal? Is he just so powerful in his insanity that he stopped giving a shit?

I just think guest cap should increase proportionate to a ride's length up to like 300 meters. A 300+ length ride gets its full guest draw, an amount shorter gets a proportionally reduced amount of guests to the park as a mini-ride merits. It's the guest cap increase that really breaks microcoasters; as simple moneymakers they're not as massively superior to a coaster with good throughput.

But any sweeping balance changes like this would need to be an optional checkbox for me to be okay with modifying the game so heavily.

Yeah, that's a bald-headed lie. I did the math for shits and giggles. Built a helix stack with a station at top and bottom, took ride length for that segment over number of turns to get circumference and hence radius of curvature: 11.8m. Convert 130kph to m/s and a = v^2/r = 11.2g.

Taking a two-unit (3m) high volume of space to be a cube, a medium turn spans, square-center to square-center, 5 squares for a 15m diameter and 17.7g.

posts.com: The circular force would be split via bank between lateral and vertical as sides of a triangle - meaning the values obey the pythagorean theorem (a^2+b^2=c^2). So the more conservative/accurate figure of 11g could be softened to something like 7.5g and 8g. Still no bueno.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9453754
Goemon cares way more about your knowledge of the video games it parodies than the actual franchise. It's the kind of series that contradicts itself on purpose to make nerds upset.

Main Series:
* Mr. Goemon (short arcade game)
* Ganbare Goemon for NES/MSX (NES plays better, MSX has ~40 unique levels, foundation for gameplay of later games)
* Ganbare Goemon 2 on NES (upgraded sequel, "story" starts here if you care)
* Ebisumaru's Kidnapping on Gameboy (Further iteration on Goemon 2, English version is on Konami GB Collection 3 for GBC)
* The four Super Nintendo games (Core series identity established, each game has weird elements)
* Uchuu Kaizoku Akogingu on PS1 (First Playstation Goemon, roughly based on gameplay of SNES games)
* The two N64 games (First is a proper 3D game, second is a 3D side scroller)
* Goemon Zero on PS2 (Soft reboot based on first N64 game, no fan translation but the complete localization that went unreleased is available online)
* Successor of the New Generation for PS1 (Mega Man X parody sidescroller)
* Goemon DS (Untranslated, series finale)

Those games were mostly developed with a lot of shared staff and had proper budgets and deadlines. Play them in any order you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9455258
Side Games:
* Goemon Gaiden 1 and 2 on NES (Dragon Quest clones)
* Ebisumaru SNES (Puzzle game)
* Goemon Sugoroku N64 (board game like Mario Party, untranslated)
* Kurofune Tou no Nazo/"Mystical Ninja Starring Goemon" on Gameboy (Different game from Ebisumaru's Kidnapping, BAD Zelda clone developed by like four guys to hit a deadline, probably the worst game)
* Kuru Nara Koi on PS1 (Budget 3D game that's very short and heavy on backtracking, untranslated)
*The two Gameboy RPGs (The first is a tie-in to the Goemon anime where you play as an isekai'd Japanese kid, the second is a Pokemon knockoff made on the cheap)

The Gaiden and Ebisumaru games are pretty good and worth your time if you like the style they're going for. The rest are low budget, rushed out cash grabs. Kuru Nara Koi is the best of the rest, but still middling and skippable.

Rehash Games:
* Dynamites Awaru on Gameboy Color (original adventure that reuses level design from SNES 2 and 4, untranslated)
* Oedo Daikaiten on PS1 (original adventure made almost entirely of recycled content from SNES 1-4 and the 3D games, plot is making fun of this by featuring a villain obsessed with recycling, untranslated)
* New Age Shutsudou on Gameboy Advance ("Port" of Successor of the New Generation that has unique levels, different dialogue, etc, untranslated)

You miss nothing by skipping these, but you can easily play and enjoy these three if you've already played the games they borrow from. There's also a GBA port of the first two SNES games on GBA with at least one new minigame. If you slot that port into a DS while playing Goemon DS, it unlocks extra content. I'd really advise waiting until both a fan translation and a way to access that content without the GBA port of SNES 1+2 becomes available to play Goemon DS.

It all looks complicated, but it just means "some of these games are skippable trash and some are repeats, mind your step."

>>9462035
1. The game is pretty text light.
2. Fixing a broken translation is easier than doing one from scratch, as you have the option to either adjust the translated game or reproduce results on the original using the translated game as a reference point. It's not drag and drop, but it's easier than if the game never got translated.
3. Both N64 Goemon games had pretty bad translations.
4. Fans already did the same for Goemon SFC 1. (Although that project is missing a bonus added to the international version, lmao).
5. "Finishing" Goemon's been a big thing in the hacking community lately and fiddling with those two games will likely make handling Goemon Sugoroku easier.
6. The other Goemon games left to translate are a bitch to work with and nobody's made headway.

>>9463989
It depends entirely in how the game is coded, and how files are handled.
I’ve hacked games where most of the text data, images with text, etc, are isolated enough that porting then to a different region is pretty straightforward, specially if the text display code maintains the limitations of the japanese version (ex.: monospace), but it can vary from game to game. Until someone actually looks into it, there’s no much point speculating.
Unfortunately, there has been zero attempts at hacking any or the N64 games (that we know of). Even though there have been very thorough hackings done for the NES, SNES and PS1 games, they were done by different hackers for a reason. Hacking on different system can be a completely different beast. There’s no guarantee anyone who has already worked on the series would be interested or capable of getting into the games on a different system.

I'm late to this party but Doomslayer's revamps are nearly done. So what I got here is:

>>>/wsg/4868569

>Pistol now bound to zoom, shoots stun bullets
>altfire is a quick sword slash (or using the Sunder gauntlet) for all weapons now
>old altfires for Wrathcaster and Inferno Rifle are baked into the primary fire
>those old attacks are rebalanced, rockets only spawn one pissed off ghost that does a 30 damage punch, Inferno Rifle vent attacks are now just a shotgun blast of plasma balls (essentially)
>bombs are gone
>daggers bound to reload now
>glass dagger now a sapphire flash knife for an AOE stun
>thunder bomb is now a thunder knife, no more bouncing off the walls or spewing homing lighting, it just hits hard.

and soon I'll be doing the last few things:
>no more passive regen for tools (Pistol, daggers, Sunder, BFG), damaging foes will recharge all of that shit
>berserk fists will be replaced with a BFG/Unmaker combo weapon.

Fuck the filesize limit.

Sunday Night Shitshow and all those other things:
You've probably noticed in the past few months a drop off in quality in the events. It started small, like with infographics not being as high-effort as usual, then snowballing into FNF infographics being retired entirely. More blaringly obvious is the connection issues as of late.

FNF/SNS used to have a team of three backing it. For their own reasons, the other two don't come online very often (don't blame them, because I don't,) leaving me to handle the events on my own, and to be completely honest, juggling two events with my own life isn't particularly fun or an easy thing to do.

The VPS subscription still has 2 weeks left, but if these issues remain unfixed, then I see little reason to renew it, and at that point you can consider SNS/FNF to be over. There's a chance we can keep going, but things are looking pretty bleak right now.

I once sat around and thought about what a Copper-styled Quake II+ mod what look like, but came up with little. I understand how Quake should be played and what things are meant to do, and Copper expands upon its concepts I already like to make them more intuitive and less annoying. With Quake II, I don't really understand what id was trying to accomplish overall or what mappers intend when placing things in their levels, and when I started brainstorming ideas, I quickly started thinking about changing fundamental aspects that I didn't like to the point where it wasn't really Quake II anymore. My best idea was just revamping the inventory menu to be neatly organized so players can quickly assess their stock instead of burning their eyes on a mono-green mess.

>>9483224
They do actually crop up, occasionally here even, a couple of the guys submitting maps to /doom/ projects are actually rather young, in their early 20s or something, and they're not bad either.

I think in part because Doom modding and stuff scratches stuff like Minecraft modding itches to a degree, but while being a shooter. Doom is also just different from the big shooters such as Calladoody, I've seen a fair amount of kids who said they thought they just didn't like shooters at all, but then try out an older one like Doom, Quake, or Half-Life, and they find that they don't, COD just doesn't offer the kind of shooter experience that they'd enjoy.
I think stuff like that is why you have the retro style FPS trend, at least in part. I haven't really seen one which I feel like I want to play, but these games are typically different from the rigidly adhered to modern AAA formula, which is probably why kids go and delve in those waters to see something that's a little different.

Doom modding is also easy, so if you want something different from both classic Doom and modern AAA shooters, you can either find or assemble it with mods, or if you have the ambition, make it yourself.

>Weathermod: Random status effects, complete shitshow

>Powerlap: You get a power-up every time you complete a lap but it's separate from your main item pool and they don't really do much
I'll keep it around for a few more games, but right now, it looks like it's the first to go on the chopping block.

I remember one of the worst times I encountered a softlock was getting to the final boss of Resident Evil Dead Aim and realizing I didn't have enough ammo to actually finish him off even with hitting every single remaining bullet. I didn't have a recent save I could go back to and scavenge more ammo in, nor do I think there was ammo left in the world to scavenge anyway. My only recourse was to restart the game and play through it again.

>>9477808
177 for the NEC PC-8801 released in 1986 by dB-soft. Its title of the game is a reference to a Japanese legislation concerning underage rape.

The game has you take the role of a rapist chasing after a woman. If you can catch her and complete a minigame where you pleasure her she marries you, If you fail to catch her or fail the minigame you are arrested. It wasn't tbe first commercial PC release to depict rape as a gameplay concept but notable the Komeito Party of the Japanese Diet referenced the game specifically during a discussion of age ratings and the limits of what a video game should be able to depict.

well not super modern anymore, but probably about 30 years ago, based on the person and on his story. It was after the end of the cold war. Guy says he was with coworkers (all US military, but in plain clothes, and no obviously military haircuts), taking a trip around eastern germany, touring castles and such. Claims they went into a random beer hall for food and drink, and not long after they arrived, happened to be there for a surreal display, in which an old guy (called "grandpa" by the staff) came in, they revealed a bunch of previously covered images of Nazi symbols and a large portrait of Hitler, and played the Nazi period version of the national anthem while everybody stood at attention, with some singing along (the old guy saluting the portrait).

Coworker says he was really lucky that despite being American military, he 1) had German ethnicity and looked the part (and the others more or less passed for "European"), 2) he knew German well enough to pass as someone who might be from around the area, and 3) none of his non-german speaking compatriots had said anything to anyone and so had plausible deniability. Said they had been eating and drinking normally before that point, but upon seeing all that (and apparently spotting a number of knives and brass knuckles and other weapons at different tables) decided they should GTFO. Compatriots thanked him for picking a lunch place that all but could have gotten them killed.

Thinking about it again, my only conclusion is that it must have been a small pocket of extremist germans hiding out in this small town. Given the recent news out of Germany, it doesn't seem as wild as it did when I first heard it.

Yes.

The graphics were mind blowing at the time, the ps1 had been out for a couple years but nothing with the quality of FF7's pre-rendered backgrounds and cinematics had been released and so many of them, the game had 3 discs.
Amazing soundtrack from start to finish.
Introduced the jrpg genre to many people. nes/snes jrpgs had some success in the west but nothing on the level of FF7 which had the attention of the entire industry and fans. FF7 was EVERYWHERE you could not escape it. Chrono Trigger? Europe had no idea it existed.
A story and characters that really connected with players that I really don't remember happening in vidya before. Cloud, Tifa, Aeris and their love triangle, Aeris's shocking death, Barret the lovable Mr T bro, bringing down the evil corporation destroying the planet, Sephiroth the iconic anime super villain at a time when anime was fresh and new in the west. Clouds mysterious past etc etc etc, it all worked.
Fun gameplay, limit breaks and materia system and million secrets and optional content.

If you were there you know how big of a impact FF7 had not only on other developers but on gamer culture in general.

>>9474518
Americans had bought vinyl and then cassettes and CD came around as a new compromise to replace both formats. Minidisc was just one too many formats to sell to the consumers, especially since having to record your CDs to a minidisc was like going backward to the days of copying records to tape.

The other big factor was that most Americans commute by car, not on foot, and so a music format which could be easily pocketed by pedestrian commuters in Europe and Japan had little appeal to American drivers whose cars had ample space for CDs or tapes.

>>9478232
The majority of MMC NES games used 128KB or 256KB carts. Most mega drive games are under 1MB. SMW and A Link to the Past are about 512KB and 720KB respectively. The most popular SNES and MD games weren't anywhere close to the maximum capacity of 4MB. Those carts were expensive as shit. The only games where they're a necessity are fighting games and squeenix cinematic jarpigs.
>And speaking as an Amiga owner, you usually had to wait for most of that 880KB to load before you got to play anything which was easily 1-2 minutes.
I don't remember the loading screens taking that long. You didn't wait for the whole floppy to load, most game were split into opening screen, game data, and level data chunks. The intro music alone could take up to 300KB while level themes were normally 96KB or less. But even if I had to wait 2 minutes for a game to load, I'd rather do that than waste 50 quids or 60 american 90s dollars on a video game. Most console owners rented their games like poorfags and had to pay for a game genie cart and the game mags that had the codes. Amiga bros could grab a game for free and get some cracktro trainer cheats as a bonus. I pity console peasants.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484950

A big part of their business model in those days was to make money on selling publishers the cartridge media; and it was also the primary anti-piracy measure. Early computer systems like the Commodore, Specturm etc had absurdly easy piracy because you could just copy the cassettes on your hi-fi. Console bootleg cartirdges existed but it was nothing like the explosion of piracy once chipped PS1s became commonplace and you could just copy a game you rented from Blockbuster onto a blank CD-R. That's when the business model changed, with Sony selling hardware at a loss and making it's money on the game licensing- It can bee argued N64 was less successful because they missed the boat on that.

To this day they still typically sell hardware on a loss- with the difference that since the advent of online distribution they can much more easily recoup the losses because they monopolise the actual marketplace.

This is a lot of the reason the games industry is such a shitshow, by the way. It's like the music industry on crack. It's all built on skimming off the fat and squeezing profits out of the people who actually MAKE the product, then fucking them over and throwing them in the trash.

>>9482052
It's bad in the state that it shipped, but I do think that it's kinda decent with some fixing, even if still rather flawed.

Of course, that's not exactly a good excuse, so I'll make the following comparison: Morrowind has bugs out the ass and somewhat janky combat, but it's a good roleplaying game with a world rich in lore and personality, while its sequel, Oblivion, has combat which is better in some ways, but has pretty shit roleplaying and dramatically genericizes the setting, while being even fucking buggier.
Morrowind, for its flaws (and it has its share), is a rather enjoyable game out of the box, even the gimped version of XBox is damn fun, but Oblivion is painfully mediocre and shallow unless you apply a fair bit of modding, the Shivering Isles expansion is a lot better than the base game, and though it's still nowhere near the highs of Morrowind, the world and quests in there are more enjoyable and interesting (even if there are things which could be improved a lot there too).

This isn't to say that Oblivion is an awful game or anything, because it really isn't, but saying "The game is decent if you fix it up a little." is a pretty big fault on the devs, and "The game is pretty good if you overhaul large parts of it." is a VERY big failure on the part of the devs, especially as a sequel to a good game which did the formula mostly better.

It seems to me that James literally only pressed the A button when playing the game and deemed it a shitty game.

>>9481518

I just finished Daikatana a while ago. The game has a lot of glaring issues, like the shitty sidekick AI, boring enemies, more than half the weapons having a shitty gimmick, and probably the worst start to a game ever (A swamp AND sewer level back to back? With the worst weapon set of all the time eras? What the fuck were they thinking?)

But even after all of that, I had fun with it. I don't know if it's some kind of Stockholm syndrome but the game actually gets better the further you go. The first era sucks ass, and the Ancient Greek era has some puzzle bullshit going on and a maze-like section toward the end. But the Medieval era has some nice aesthetics and you're finally getting decent weapons again, and finally, the Modern era has the best weapon set with only two bad weapons (The Ice gun and the Laser mine) and the level design gets better too.

If the game didn't had that rocky development I think it would've been better. Scaling back the gimmicks of the weapons, making the levels larger and with more enemies, and removing the AI partners would already make the game 10 times better. It's such a crime that a game with such huge mobility is barely using it for something. Maxing out the Acro skill + lots of weapons having huge knockback that allow you to get even higher is great on paper, but the level design doesn't support this.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9479878
I don't have a complete list, but I know these six are ones I wouldn't do without:
Time Crisis
Area 51
Tekken Tag Tournament
Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3
Chronicles of Mysteria
Gauntlet: Dark Legacy

I think the key to success for arcades is to provide things that you can't easily replicate on a home console: Unique controls like light guns, steering wheels/racing pedals, joysticks, etc that the average person wouldn't have, games that thrive on having your opponent in person and a crowd watching you, and games that are best played co-op with friends. The only other problem is that you need to keep getting fresh entertainment with new games or content, but I think that could be solved pretty easily in the modern era of internet connectivity and devs providing updates.

posts.sub: Still the best retro fun racer
posts.com:
100% intuitive because everyone is familiar with the universe, great controls, very diverse graphics and settings, great course design with a lot of corners and shortcuts (still the best in the series: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/jThXtZIIwK4), amazing battle mode

>Double Dash
Charming but shitty controls because of long cars and the worst course design in the series
>Super Mario Kart
Amazing game and high difficulty with tricky drifting, but it's inarguably very clunky. Course design is hit and miss but consistently just a bit ugly
>Diddy Kong Racing
Dumbest course-select screen in the history of video games. Marred by some shitty story mode and collectathon elements because Rare can't help themselves. Course design not great
>Crash Team Racing
Lacks the charm of Mario, samey visuals, items aren't as intuitive and leaving you guessing what they really do and, similar to DKR, dumb story mode to unlock important stuff

I'll say it again:
Mario Kart 64 is the best multiplayer kart-racer to the point anyone can pick it up, play it and have fun, the later MK games are obnoxiously chaotic imo (DS is pretty good though).
Diddy Kong Racing provides one of the most fun single player experiences in the kart genre. the three vehicles also provide some nice variety even if the tracks are short.
CTR is an amazingly deep game for time trial-enthusiasts and the remake provides a fuck ton of content even if imo the physics and controls arent as good as the ps1 classic.

posts.name: Anonymous

>Mario Kart 64's track design and gameplay polarised critics. The game was panned for being un-innovative (Schneider),[11] too easy (Caron),[53] and simple and monotonous (Ward and Nick Ferguson from Edge).[63][50][63] Computer and Video Games's Ed Lomas[45] and N64 Magazine's Jonathan Nash felt that success was too dependent on getting the right power-ups.[54] Morley disliked Mario Kart 64's wide, motorway-like track design by saying that it did not provide an "adrenaline filled" experience which players might have hoped for.[59] Critics also found fault in the game's use of rubberband difficulty balancing, recognising that it gave the enemy AI an unfair advantage.[59][11][54] Technical issues such as poor collision detection and lag in the four-player "Battle Mode" were also noted.[48][56][54]

>Critics debated the game's presentation and visuals. Detractors of the graphics felt they lacked detail (Tom Gulse from Computer and Video Games and Peer Schneider from IGN),[45][11] weren't better enough than the previous 16-bit entry (AllGame's Scott McCall and Neil West from Next Generation),[44][56] and failed to fully benefit from the N64's power (Francois Caron of Jeuxvideo.com).[53] The use of 2D sprites was a common critique,[53] West arguing that it made the game look 16-bit.[56]

Mario Kart 64 was never good. Nostalgia is a hell of a drug.

>>9485084
Both versions have advantages. The remake changes the turbo mechanics so you can go ridiculously fast and adds extra time trials to utilise them, but it makes the game less fun with friends. The remake has added tracks from CNK and new tracks, but the quality is a little spottier. The remake has many more cosmetic options but they're tied to a cash shop. All the unlockable characters from the original can still be unlocked the original way.
I'd go with the original and maybe check out the remake if you want more.

Either way, do the time trials. They're secretly the best part of the game.

Some tips for FNR3
>don't punch yourself out
>practice parrying and rolling/leaning

>practice blocking/leaning your way out of the flash KO minigame

>I'm playing MRA2 as well. Do you have any tip for a first-timer?
Nothing really specific to this games campaign as I haven't really bothered with finding many secrets or anything, but some basic tips on raising monsters, you may already know all this but....

Always make sure you relieve monsters "stress" and "fatigue", always let it rest obviously but also use items like oil or mintcandy to remove fatigue after training and battles. Battling itself actually helps remove monsters stress. As you accumulate larger amounts of cash, it's definitely good to prioritize buying all the more expensive stress relieving, fatigue relieving, and sleep helping items you'll see in the shop like the cups and gems, as can afford them of course, don't skip out on them, they'll make it easier for new monsters. Also don't let your monster get fat or malnourished, fat monsters get fatigued more and underweight monsters get stressed more.

Also take it easy on baby monsters, just do the most basic training until its more mature aka when Holly tells gives you that cue that it's an "important time" or whatever she says, that's when you start the coach routines

Always focus on like 3, maybe 4 main stats to train your monster in. Having a balanced monster doesn't really work because there's only so much time you can put into training during its lifespan, you want your monster to excel hard in specific areas, not be average in many areas, so take that into consideration when deciding what monster you wanna raise and how you want it to grow/what moves you want it to learn

When you're stronger and start doing sparring with the intention of learning new moves specifically, it's not really worth it unless you're gonna learn a new move, so don't bother wasting the money and time unless it says there's a chance your monster will learn a new move, and honestly I say theres no shame in saving before and restarting until you learn the move

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9483467
>Memes aside, when did you find out?

That's a good question, because i don't even remember. As a kid the first time I saw SMB2 was at an arcade (yes, an arcade) that also sold NES games at the front counter. And they had a TV set with a NES set up that was playing Mario Bros. 2. They would let people try the game out if you asked. I would rent the game, but never owned it. I owned SMB1, SMB3, and SMW, but never SMB2. Super Mario Bros. 2 did stand out as being a little different from the other games in the series. As a kid, I thought SMB3 was a step backwards from SMB2 in many ways. Ni selectable characters, no being able to pick up anything and throw it. Though the game did add the ability to pick up some objects. But at the same time, I never really suspected that it was a different game. because Zelda II on the NES was different from the first Zelda as well. Plus Nintendo did a good job adapting the characters from SMB2 into the Mario cannon. Also, the Super Mario Bros Super Show was on TV around the same time, which used a lot of characters from SMB2, but no Wart.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9487396
>>SMB2 (J) was considered too difficult for western kids/gamers
>That's just a meme. NoA didn't want to release it because they thought an expert level pack would be a tough sell. Especially when renting is a thing and you can easily satisfy your curiosity of what "harder Mario" is by just renting it once.

The Japanese Super Mario Bros. 2 was sold as a Disk system game in Japan, and was marketed to the Japanese as hard mode Mario Bros. But in 1987-1988, the game did look dated for a NES game in comparison to the other third party NES games from Konami and Capcom. It looked way too much like the first game. Doki Doki Panic did look better overall, and wasn't geared towards a hard mode. Localising it was the best thing to do. It was a game made by EAD. Also, because Doki Doki Panic was part of a special event in Japan, Nintendo did not own the characters. They did re-release Doki Doki Panic in Japan as Super Mario Bros. USA on cartridge. The original Doki Doki was on the Disk system.
